citation.article-title: Amycolatopsis australiensis sp. nov., an actinomycete isolated from arid soils
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Amycolatopsis australiensis sp. nov.
Amycolatopsis australiensis (aus.tra.li.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. australiensis pertaining to Australia, the source of the soil from which the first strains were isolated).
Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-acid–alcohol-fast, non-motile actinobacteria that form extensively branched substrate mycelia that fragment into squarish, rod-shaped elements.

Abundant, white aerial hyphae and pale-yellow substrate mycelia are formed on modified Bennett's agar supplemented with mannitol and soybean flour; a medium-yellow diffusible pigment is evident on this medium.
Melanin pigments are not produced on peptone-yeast extract-iron or tyrosine agars.
Good growth occurs between 28 and 45 °C, and from pH 5 to 7.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite; elastin, Tween 40 and uric acid are degraded.

d(+)-Arabitol, d(+)-cellobiose, dextrin, d(+)-galactose, d(+)-glucose, glycerol, glycogen, myo-inositol, α-lactose, d(+)-maltose, d(+)-mannitol, d(+)-melezitose, d(+)-raffinose, sucrose, d(+)-trehalose, xylitol, d(+)-xylose (all at 1 %, w/v) and citric acid, oxalic acid and propionic acid (all at 0.1 %, w/v) are used as sole carbon sources, but adonitol, meso-erythritol, d(+)-melibiose, methyl α-d-glucoside, d(+)-ribose, d(−)-sorbitol (all at 1 %, w/v) and sodium benzoate, sodium lactate and sodium mucate (at 0.1 %, w/v) are not.
Acid is formed from d(+)-arabitol, d(+)-glucose, glycerol, glycogen, d(+)-mannose and d(+)-turanose, but not from dulcitol, d(+)-ribose or xylitol.

The organism is sensitive to novobiocin (10 μg ml−1), penicillin G (20 μg ml−1), rifampicin (10 μg ml−1) and streptomycin sulphate (16 μg ml−1), but resistant to gentamicin sulphate (5 μg ml−1), neomycin sulphate (8 μg ml−1), polymyxin B sulphate (50 μg ml−1) and tobramycin sulphate (8 μg ml−1).
Activity is shown against B. subtilis ATCC 6633 and S. cerevisiae ATCC 9763 but not against Candida albicans ATCC 10231.
Additional phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1.
The type strain, GY048T (=DSM 44671T=NCIMB 14142T), was isolated from arid Australian soils.
